messageBody:
Personally, I think the separation of test and
production code is the biggest limitation of JUnit and
why I don't use it. It's a "good thing" to have the
tests for a class included in the class. The classes
are self contained. Why go back to the C++ days of
having separate files for the same class: .h, .cpp,
test.cpp.

I'm sure different teams are have different work
pactices, but when the tests are in a separate class,
tests don't get updated/created. The biggest
impediment to creating unit tests was the need to
crack open a separate test class.

Thanks,
David Jared

>

> MyClass$TestMyClass.class );
> > }

> > public static class TestMyClass extends TestCase
> {
> > // The setup

> > //test code here

> > }
> > }
> > }
> >
> > So, the questions are:
> > Can this kind of setup be done with JUnit or am I
> going to do

> JUnit works?
> > I guess that my Java knowledge still is far from
> expert level...
> >
> > TIA, Santi.
